key_insight: GateFusion replaces brittle late fusion with a hierarchical gated decoder that enables fine-grained, layer-wise cross-modal interactions between strong pretrained audio and visual encoders, improving robustness of frame-level active speaker detection.
problem_solved: Existing ASD systems using late fusion fail to capture detailed audioâ€“visual interactions across scales and layers, reducing accuracy in unconstrained, noisy, or multi-speaker scenarios.
method: Leverage strong pretrained unimodal encoders for audio and visual streams to extract rich features.
Introduce a Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder (HiGat) that applies gating and cross-attention across multiple levels/timescales to selectively combine modalities.
Use the fused representations for frame-level active speaker classification, preserving fine-grained temporal and spatial cues missed by late fusion.
impact: GateFusion offers practitioners a modular way to fuse pretrained encoders that better models cross-modal dependencies, yielding more robust ASD in real-world video/audio settings and a template for other multimodal tasks.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: parallel pretrained audio and visual encoders feeding into the Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder with gated connections illustrated by adjustable valves.
Gating detail inset: close-up showing how gating weights modulate cross-modal feature flow across layers/time.
Performance schematic: conceptual comparison (late fusion vs GateFusion) showing improved interaction capture and robustness (no raw numbers).
Qualitative examples: video frames with audio waveform and detected active-speaker heatmap/overlay to show practical outputs.
paper_title: GateFusion: Hierarchical Gated Cross-Modal Fusion for Active Speaker Detection
paper_authors: Yu Wang, Juhyung Ha, Frangil M. Ramirez, Yuchen Wang, David J. Crandall
